Award.AwardTitle: RET in Engineering and Computer Science Site: Advanced Content in Computational Engineering and Science Standards for Teachers (ACCESS 4Teachers)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award renews an exemplary Research Experience for Teachers (RET) Site at the University of Southern California (USC). The USC Viterbi School of Engineering has partnered with the Los Angeles Unified School District (LAUSD) to develop an integrated engineering and computer science RET Site targeting middle school science and math educators. The resulting program is a collaborative research-based professional development effort that combines the computer science, engineering, technological, and pedagogical expertise of USC faculty with inner-city teachers in 6th- thru 8th-grade science and math classrooms in the LAUSD. The primary goals of the program are to: (1) increase teachers' knowledge of computationally-focused science and engineering technologies; (2) increase middle school teachers' disciplinary pedagogic competence in computer science, engineering, and applied math through a comprehensive program that includes targeted lab-based research experiences focused on computer science and engineering aligned with Next Generation Science Standards, Common Core Math Standards, and advanced lesson study; and (3) build and maintain long-term collaborative partnerships between LAUSD middle school teachers and the research community that positively impact student achievement and career paths.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in the strong research foundation at the core of the RET Site combined with a leadership team that excels at both research and educational outreach. This RET Site is focused on innovative, societally relevant computer science and engineering research and brings this research to high-need middle school science and math teachers using lesson-study focused professional development approaches. The goal is to facilitate team teaching between math and science teachers to integrate their subject areas with engineering and computer science problem solving aligned with the Next Generation Science and the Common Core Math standards. This project effectively translates research into educational practice and provides exemplary models for weaving computing and engineering concepts into K-12 education.

The RET Site program has significant broader impacts. It will result in innovative curricula that not only address new curriculum standards, but also address an area of significant need in middle school content. It will provide video-based middle school lesson exemplars and units of study for teachers nationwide to use in their classrooms. The LAUSD, the second largest public school district in the United States, has a significant population of students from under-represented groups. Thus this project has the potential to have a positive influence on many students who are traditionally under-represented as computer scientists and engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The USC Viterbi School of Engineering Advanced Content in Computational Engineering and Science Standards for Teachers Research Experience for Teachers (ACCESS 4 Teachers RET) program was part of Viterbi School of Engineering?s K-12 Center, a School-wide initiative at USC in which engineering faculty collaborated with K-12 teachers and their students. This was a comprehensive teacher professional development program in which 58 teachers from elementary through high school participated in intensive summer research experiences in Viterbi engineering labs, built K-12 curricula based on the laboratory research content that they learned in the labs, and implemented the new curricula in their classrooms. The program had the combined intent of bringing contemporary engineering research to K-12 students and improving student achievement in computer science, engineering and mathematics through scientific inquiry. Initially the RET was designed to serve middle school teachers, however for the final three years, we extended its reach to upper grade elementary school teachers and high school teachers as a means of engaging in vertically aligned curricula with teams of teachers planning and implementing curricula together across the K-12 landscape.

Key outcomes for the ACCESS 4 Teachers RET Program include: (1)  Increased teachers? STEM teaching efficacy and content knowledge; (2) increased students? STEM motivation and engagement; (3) increased science literacy; (4) increased teachers? cyber-safety understanding; and (5)  pedagogical expertise in infusing cyber-safety into their classrooms resulting from the RET experience.

In terms of intellectual merits, we performed multiple assessments of the RET Site program.  We compared the STEM teaching efficacy of the ACCESS 4 Teachers RET participants to other national studies.  For this, we used the science teaching efficacy beliefs instrument- revised (STEBI-R).  Mean scores for ACCESS 4 Teachers RET participants were compared to non-RET groups. Cumulatively, the RET teachers had a mean STEM teaching efficacy of 3.81 while the national average is 2.47. As a second teacher assessment, we compared teacher instructional performance using a teacher observational metric, the teacher performance observational rubric (TPOR), to other instructional performance averages.  The mean score on the TPOR cumulatively for the  RET participants was 3.91 compared to an average on research conducted on other projects statewide of 3.14. The participating RET teachers had a 29.7 summed percent gain pre-to-post RET experience.

In addition to conducting teacher performance assessments, we measured changes in student performance in the classrooms of the teachers who participated in RET Site. Since one of the ACCESS 4 Teachers RET program?s goals was to increase students STEM literacy, our curriculum interventions were designed to target STEM literacy, and we used this metric as an indicator of student success. We administered a qualitative reading inventory for STEM literacy in each grade level. This inventory includes reading comprehension, reading vocabulary in science, and science writing. These data are aligned with the grade level Common Core Standards in English Language Arts, the Next Generation Science Standards, and represented subject and grade specific literacy. The results indicated a summary score of 41.5% across program years. These are not comparable to other such measures as they are curriculum specific  for each teacher.

We also measured student motivation, interest, and engagement in science and engineering using a Motivation for Computer Science and Engineering questionnaire, a four-point Likert-type instrument with 11 subscales. Summary gains across the RET?s program years were 36.9%. Finally, to assess the conceptual knowledge gained from the curriculum that the teachers co-created during the RET?s summer content-to-pedagogy workshops, the teachers administered subject-specific concept inventories as achievement tests for each teacher-created unit of study.  The summed gains for these student assessments summarily are  41.6% across science subdisciplines.

In terms of broader impacts, the ACCESS 4 Teachers RET results indicate that students made significant gains during the curricular intervention implemented in the teachers? classrooms and resulting from their teachers? participation in the RET program. Moreover, the participating teachers? students gained knowledge, increased their engineering and computer science interest and motivation, and demonstrated gains in science literacy as well. The student- and teacher-focused RET Site program outcomes have demonstrated that a teacher intervention results in both teacher and student outcome gains.  The photos represent the program in action.
